How to Cite International Journal of Production Economics in APA Format

Complete guide to citing International Journal of Production Economics in APA 7th edition with examples, unique formatting requirements, and common issues specific to this source.

International Journal of Production Economics presents unique citation challenges that require specific guidance beyond general source type rules. This page provides targeted help for finding citation information, handling International Journal of Production Economics's particular format requirements, and avoiding common mistakes specific to this platform.

Quick Reference: International Journal of Production Economics Citations

Reference List Format:
Author, A. A., & Author, B. B. (Year). Title of article. Title of Journal, volume(issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx

International Journal of Production Economics-Specific Notes:
When citing articles from the International Journal of Production Economics in APA 7th edition, there are no unique formatting requirements specific to this journal that differ from the general APA guidelines for journal articles. However, it's crucial to follow the standard APA format for journal citations, which includes listing up to 20 authors. This is a key detail, as APA 7th edition allows for the inclusion of all authors' names if there are 20 or fewer, which is a shift from the previous edition that required an ellipsis after the 6th author when a work had more than seven authors.

A common point of confusion arises when dealing with articles that have multiple authors. Students often mistakenly truncate the author list prematurely, not realizing that all authors should be listed if the total is 20 or fewer. For the International Journal of Production Economics, this means paying careful attention to the author list and ensuring each author is credited in the citation. The format follows the pattern: Author, A. A., Author, B. B., & Author, C. C. (Year). Title of the article. Journal Name, Volume(Issue), page range. https://doi.org/xxx

To avoid common mistakes, students should double-check the total number of authors and consult the journal's website or their library's database to ensure they have the correct and complete list of authors. Additionally, it is essential to include the digital object identifier (DOI) in the citation, as it provides a permanent link to the article. By adhering to these practices, students can accurately cite articles from the International Journal of Production Economics and avoid common pitfalls related to author listing and DOI inclusion.

Finding citation information for articles published in the International Journal of Production Economics requires navigating through specific platforms that host academic journals. Here‚Äôs a step-by-step guide to locating the necessary citation details such as the author, publication date, title, and URL/access information for articles from this journal.

Accessing the Journal

  1. Initial Search: Start by searching for the article using a reliable academic database or directly via the journal's publisher website (typically Elsevier for this journal). Use Google Scholar or your library‚Äôs electronic resources to access the journal's specific webpage.

  2. Navigating to Articles: Once on the journal‚Äôs homepage, use the search function to locate a specific article. You can search by title, author, or keywords related to your topic of interest.

Finding Citation Information

  • Author(s): On the article‚Äôs landing page, the author byline is typically located near the top of the page, either directly under the title or in a section labeled "Authors." If there are multiple authors, all names will be listed, often with institutional affiliations.

  • Publication Date: The publication date is usually found directly below the author‚Äôs information or alongside the article title. It often includes the day, month, and year of publication.

  • Title of the Article: The title is prominently displayed at the top of the article‚Äôs webpage. Ensure you copy it exactly as it appears, including any subtitles.

  • URL/Access Information: The URL can be found in your browser‚Äôs address bar when you are on the article‚Äôs webpage. Make sure to copy the complete link. If accessing through a library database, note that the URL might be a proxy link specific to your institution.

Additional Tips

  • DOI (Digital Object Identifier): For academic articles, always look for the DOI, typically located near the article‚Äôs title or abstract. The DOI provides a permanent link to the article and is crucial for APA citations.

  • Abstract and Keywords: While not part of the citation, the abstract and keywords can help confirm that you have located the correct article. These are generally found below the title and authors.

Unique Aspects of International Journal of Production Economics

  • Publisher‚Äôs Website: As the International Journal of Production Economics is published by Elsevier, navigating through their platform (ScienceDirect) is beneficial. ScienceDirect provides structured layouts with clear sections for authors, affiliations, and publication details.

By carefully navigating these resources and utilizing the structured layout provided by platforms like ScienceDirect, students can efficiently gather all necessary citation details for their academic writing.

Step-by-Step: Creating Your International Journal of Production Economics Citation

How to Create an APA Citation for the International Journal of Production Economics

Creating a citation in APA format for an article from the International Journal of Production Economics can seem overwhelming at first. However, by following these simple steps, you will be able to create accurate citations with ease. This guide is designed for beginners and will walk you through the process step-by-step.

What You Need

  • Access to the article you want to cite
  • Basic understanding of APA format
  • A citation management tool (optional but helpful)
  • A note-taking application or paper for jotting down information

Step-by-Step Instructions

  1. Identify the Article Information
    - Action: Locate the article you want to cite. This will typically be found on the journal's website or a database where the journal is published.
    - Verification: Ensure you have the following details: the authors' names, publication year, article title, journal title, volume number, issue number, page range, and a DOI (Digital Object Identifier) if available.
    - Time Estimate: 5-10 minutes
    - Tip: If you are using an academic database, many of these details are usually displayed prominently on the article page.

  2. Format the Authors‚Äô Names
    - Action: Write the authors' last names followed by their initials. If there are multiple authors, separate them with commas and use an ampersand (&) before the last author's name.
    - Verification: Double-check the spelling of the authors' names to ensure accuracy.
    - Time Estimate: 2-5 minutes
    - Tip: For articles with more than 20 authors, refer to the APA manual for guidance on how to format them.

  3. Include the Publication Year
    - Action: After the authors' names, insert the year of publication in parentheses. Follow this with a period.
    - Verification: Confirm that you have the correct year by checking the article's publication date.
    - Time Estimate: 1 minute
    - Tip: Ensure the year is not confused with the date of online publication, if applicable.

  4. Write the Title of the Article
    - Action: Next, write the title of the article in sentence case. This means only the first word of the title and any proper nouns should be capitalized. End this section with a period.
    - Verification: Make sure you include the full title as it appears in the article.
    - Time Estimate: 3-5 minutes
    - Tip: If the title is long, focus on clarity and conciseness.

  5. Include the Journal Title, Volume, and Issue
    - Action: Write the journal title in italics, following it with the volume number in italics. If there is an issue number, place it in parentheses directly after the volume number (not italicized). End this portion with a comma.
    - Verification: Check that you are using the correct journal title and corresponding volume and issue numbers.
    - Time Estimate: 3-5 minutes
    - Tip: Use the journal's official website to verify the title and volume information.

  6. Add the Page Range
    - Action: After the volume and issue, include the page range of the article. This should be formatted as "pages." For example, if the article spans pages 123-145, it would be written as "123-145." End this section with a period.
    - Verification: Confirm that you have the correct page numbers by cross-referencing with the article itself.
    - Time Estimate: 2-3 minutes
    - Tip: Make sure to include all pages that the article covers.

  7. Insert the DOI
    - Action: Finally, if a DOI is available, include it at the end of the citation. Format it as "https://doi.org/xxxxx" where "xxxxx" is the DOI number.
    - Verification: Double-check that the DOI is correct and active by clicking on it.
    - Time Estimate: 2-5 minutes
    - Tip: If a DOI is not available, you may use the URL of the article instead, but ensure it leads directly to the article.

  8. Review Your Citation
    - Action: Look over your entire citation to ensure all elements are in the correct order and properly formatted according to APA guidelines.
    - Verification: Compare your citation against an APA style guide or use an online citation generator for reference.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes
    - Tip: It's beneficial to have a peer review your citation or to use a citation management tool that can help format it correctly.

In-Text Citation (Narrative Format):

Scenario Description: An article with no clear author, focusing on recent trends in production economics.

In-Text Citation (Parenthetical Format):
("Trends in Production Economics," 2023)

In-Text Citation (Narrative Format):
"Trends in Production Economics" (2023) highlights recent trends in the field.

Notes: Articles without a specific author use the title in place of the author‚Äôs name, which is a special case in citation formatting.

Common Issues When Citing International Journal of Production Economics

Problem 1: Identifying Authors

Issue Description:
Students often struggle with correctly identifying the authors of articles from the International Journal of Production Economics (IJPE). This can lead to incorrect citations if authors are omitted or misattributed.

Why It Happens:
IJPE, like many academic journals, lists multiple authors for a single article. This can be challenging if the authors are not clearly delineated or if their roles (e.g., corresponding author) are not adequately highlighted on the journal's interface.

Solution:
1. Navigate to the article's page on the IJPE website.
2. Look for the "Authors" section, usually positioned at the top of the article page or near the abstract.
3. Carefully list all authors in the order presented, as APA 7th edition requires maintaining the original order.
4. If the authors' names are abbreviated, find the full names often available in the article's PDF or by checking the authors' institutional affiliations.

Example:
- Before: J. Smith, A. Brown
- After: Smith, J., & Brown, A.

Problem 2: Formatting Date of Publication

Issue Description:
Incorrect date formatting is a common issue, particularly for journals that publish articles online ahead of print.

Why It Happens:
IJPE articles may have different "available online" dates and actual "published" dates. Students often confuse these two, leading to incorrect date citation.

Solution:
1. Check the article's page for the specific "published online" date, usually near the title or abstract.
2. Use the online publication date if the article has not yet been assigned to a specific issue.
3. Format the date in accordance with APA guidelines: (Year, Month Day).

Example:
- Before: 2023
- After: (2023, July 15)

Problem 3: Handling URLs

Issue Description:
Students frequently mishandle URLs, either by omitting them or including incomplete links in their citations.

Why It Happens:
IJPE often uses DOI (Digital Object Identifier) links, which may be overlooked by students unfamiliar with how to properly format these in APA style.

Solution:
1. Locate the DOI on the article‚Äôs page, usually listed under the title or abstract.
2. Use the DOI link in the format: "https://doi.org/xxxx" as APA 7th edition prefers DOIs over URLs.
3. If a DOI is unavailable, use the direct URL of the article.

Example:
- Before: www.elsevier.com/ijpe-article
- After: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijpe.2023.105782

Problem 4: Access Requirements

Issue Description:
Students can struggle with properly citing articles if they have access restrictions, such as subscription requirements.

Why It Happens:
IJPE articles may require institutional access, leading students to bypass proper access links or cite incomplete information.

Solution:
1. Ensure access through university or institutional library portals.
2. If access is unavailable, seek alternative routes like contacting authors or using interlibrary loans.
3. Always cite the DOI or stable URL, regardless of access issues, as this maintains consistency and allows others to locate the article.

Example:
- Before: Article accessed through university library.
- After: "Retrieved from https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijpe.2023.105782"

By understanding these specific challenges and following the provided solutions, students can accurately cite articles from the International Journal of Production Economics in APA 7th edition format, ensuring compliance and scholarly integrity.

Frequently Asked Questions About International Journal of Production Economics

Q: How can I find the necessary citation information for an article from the International Journal of Production Economics on its website?

A: Visit the journal's website and navigate to the article you are interested in. Look for the "Cite" or "Citation" tool often provided, which generates an APA citation. You can also find details such as author names, publication date, article title, and DOI directly on the article's page.

Q: How should I handle unique author formats when citing from the International Journal of Production Economics in APA style?

A: The International Journal of Production Economics sometimes lists authors with initials and surnames. In APA format, list authors by last name followed by initials without spaces (e.g., Smith, J. A.). If there are multiple authors, separate them with commas and use an ampersand before the last author's name.

Q: What is the proper way to format publication dates when citing articles from the International Journal of Production Economics?

A: Articles from the International Journal of Production Economics usually provide a specific publication date. In APA format, use the year first, followed by the month and day if available (e.g., 2023, March 15). If only the year is available, use just the year.

Q: Are there specific URL or access requirements when citing online articles from the International Journal of Production Economics in APA?

A: In APA format, include the DOI if available, formatted as a URL (e.g., https://doi.org/xx.xxxx/xxxxxx). If no DOI is available, use the URL of the journal‚Äôs website or the direct link to the article, ensuring it leads to the full text or abstract.

Q: How does citing an article from the International Journal of Production Economics differ from other journal articles in APA format?

A: Citing articles from the International Journal of Production Economics in APA format generally follows standard journal article guidelines, but attention should be paid to the DOI format and potentially unique author listing conventions. Unlike some journals, this journal often provides a DOI, which should be included in the citation for easy access.
